section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need a collection of items like buttons or rocks.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Creature Features today, we talked about how to sort animals by their features, like whether or not they have hair.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Sorting In this activity, we will first sort a collection of items like buttons or rocks, and then we will sort animals. Discuss with children different ways they could sort the collection, such as by size, color, or shape.
Set Up Put the unsorted collection on the table.
Ask How should we sort these? Invite children to sort the collection by attribute.
Play Show each Activity Card one at a time. Ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.

Sort Invite children to take turns sorting the cards by different attributes, such as green and not green, or two legs and more than two legs. After the Activity Cards are sorted, ask children to count the cards in each group and say how many cards there are in that group.
Repeat Ask children to sort by a different attribute, allowing each child to have a turn choosing an attribute.

Talk About Sorting Ask children to talk about the different ways they sorted. Help them understand that objects can be sorted into different categories, and that the categories can change depending on the objects.

To simplify the activity, use fewer manipulatives and/or fewer cards. Determine which attribute to use for sorting and model the activity while thinking aloud. For example, I am looking for all the green animals. Is this animal green? It is! I will put it in this pile.
Have children combine the collection and Activity Cards into one set. Challenge children to sort this new, more diverse set.

Begin the activity by reviewing the Activity Cards and the names of the animals and animal features. You can also encourage children to use names of the animals or animal features from their home language as they sort the cards.
During the activity, ask each child in the group to hold one picture card. Instead of sorting just the cards, have children pretend to be that animal and physically sort themselves into two groups.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Before beginning the lesson, gather the Activity Cards.
Prepare If possible, find and bookmark several child-friendly Internet sites about animals. As an alternative to online research, gather several reference books about animals.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Creature Features, we talked about how the book helped us learn more about animals. One way to learn more is to look up answers to questions we are curious about.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the word curious. Use the curious Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: I will give each of you an animal card. You will think of something you wonder about for that animal. Then we’ll look for an answer together.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Give each child an animal card and check that children know which animal is on their card. Give children time to look at their card and think about what they wonder about that animal.
Ask What do you wonder about your animal? Can you share a “why” question about that animal? Discuss the question and possible answers. Then think aloud as you look up the answer.
Repeat Continue until each child has asked a question.

Talk About Sorting Remind children how they practiced sorting animals by features you can see, like color and number of legs. Now that they’ve learned more about each animal, ask children to think of new ways to sort the animals, like by what they eat or when they sleep.
To simplify the activity, select one animal card and help children generate questions about that animal as a group.

Have children think of follow-up questions now that they have answers to a first question. What new things do they wonder? For example, if they found out zebras have tails to swat flies, they might wonder if dog tails also swat flies.

For Spanish-speaking children, point out that curious and curioso/a are cognates. Research shows that PreK children benefit from explicit instruction about words that are cognates. Cognate awareness helps children acquire a second language.

Children may have trouble finding the words to ask questions. Encourage them to use gestures as well. Give children time to think about their words. You can also repeat and rephrase the children’s questions to make them easier to answer, and provide prompts that children can complete.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Connecting Cubes to represent ducks.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Creature Features today, we talked about animal features. Some animals had the same features, and some had different features.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the words same and different. Use the same and different Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will use ducks to help us practice counting and to talk about groups that are the same and different.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Line up 10 Connecting Cube “ducks,” and ask a child to count out a certain amount of ducks from the group and place them aside.

Ask Once there are two groups of cubes, ask another child to count both groups and say if the number of ducks in each group is the same or different. Then ask the first child to return the ducks to the original line-up and count the entire group again. Are there still 10 ducks?
Repeat Do the activity again so that all children have a chance to count out groups of ducks from 10 and compare the two groups.

Talk About 10 Talk with children about how the different groups had 10 ducks in all, no matter how the 10 cubes were counted. Remind children that we can separate the number 10 in different ways, and that the order in which we count does not affect how many ducks there are in all.

To simplify this activity, use six ducks. Have the children count the ducks along with you. Divide the ducks into two groups and have the children count the total in each group. Then ask if the two groups are the same or different.
Invite children to fill in math sentence frames to demonstrate how the two groups of ducks always add up to 10. For example, + = 10
Begin the activity by reviewing the number names for 1–10 to support multilingual learners. For Spanish-speaking children, you can also point out that different and differente are cognates.
As a way to further engage children and help them strengthen their fine motor skills, invite them to draw pictures of ducks to use during the activity instead of Connecting Cubes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For each pair of children, you will need an even number of Connecting Cubes to represent “frogs” and a piece of blue paper to be the “frog pond.”

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Fantastic Feet today, we separated the animal feet into two groups with the same number of feet in each group.
In this activity, we will separate frogs into equal groups. Some will stay swimming in the pond, and some will jump out of the pond.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Distribute blue paper and Connecting Cubes to each pair of children, and explain what each represents.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: The first partner will put all of the frogs in the pond. Then that partner will decide how many frogs should jump out and how many should stay in the pond to make the groups equal. The second partner will count how many frogs are in each group and say whether or not the two groups have the same number of frogs.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Collect the frogs from the partners. Distribute a different, even number of Connecting Cubes to each pair. Have the partners switch roles.

Talk About Equal Groups Talk with children about what happens when you separate objects into equal groups. Help children notice that the numbers in each group are the same, or equal. Relate the concept to sharing and how a child might divide something equally, like a snack or some toys, with a friend.
Encourage children to use their fingers for counting as additional support. Guide them to use two hands: one to show the frogs in the pond and the other to represent the frogs that jumped out.
Invite children to write number sentences to represent the two groups of frogs and the total number of frogs. Offer a math sentence frame that looks like this: + = .
Begin the activity by reviewing the number names from one to ten. You can encourage children to use number names from their home language as they count.

Consider using larger or smaller manipulatives instead of Connecting Cubes to support children’s fine motor needs. Alternately, ask children to cut out shapes from green paper and use those as “frogs” in the activity.
